important_phrase: Most District growers affected by poor soil moisture levels benefited from increased precipitation in July and August
Retailers reported that sales were below expectations while inventories were higher than a year earlier
There were increased instances of businesses passing on higher costs to consumers
Consumer loan demand ranged from being steady to down across the District
Activity six months from now was expected to be similar to current levels with manufacturers anticipating the price increases for both raw materials and finished goods to moderate
Contacts reported that sales activity was mixed; some District contacts noted further weakening while others reported modest strengthening
District merchants reported that sales were below expectations for July and August
According to most respondents, the near-term outlook is for "more of the same" or further slowing, with some signs of improvement expected in 2009

Overall labor supply has improved, with one contact attributing the influx of candidates to the poor economic climate; nonetheless, filling upper-level positions remains a challenge for most staffing firms
Two-thirds of manufacturing contacts have reduced their workforce--generally modestly--from year-ago levels
The Rhode Island market is also described as slow but not dismal
Tourism in the Boston area has been "surprisingly good
Hay supplies improved with new cuttings, and pastures were in good shape
Residential construction declined and nonresidential construction showed further signs of slowing
Wge pressures remained limited outside of skilled labor positions that continue to experience shortages
The volume of consumer credit was little changed, despite a decline in approval rates due to continued tightening in lending standards
A pharmaceutical manufacturer reported strong growth in new hires
However, absorption rates of residential housing improved
Spending on automobiles remained slow
Oil, gas, and coal production has been steady to increasing during the past six weeks
Energy production was steady to increasing
Demand for business lending has been steady to slightly down
On a year-over-year basis, reports were evenly split between production slowdowns and increases
Although backlogs remain relatively strong, inquiries have declined
Employment levels and wages were relatively stable
Livestock operators culled their herds at a higher-than-normal rate due to elevated feed costs and poor pasture conditions
The Eleventh District economy expanded modestly in late July and August
The labor market remained relatively tight and most contacts reported flat to moderate hiring
Eleventh District financial services contacts report relatively satisfactory conditions despite the uncertain national financial environment
Contacts noted clients were cautious to hire because of a slower national economy, rising costs and upcoming elections
Office leasing activity remained positive but the pace was slower
Inventory levels improved as manufacturers reduced production and dealers cut prices
Profit margins at bio-fuel firms improved with lower crop prices
Labor markets softened, but some firms continued to report labor shortages
Restaurant contacts indicated that menu prices were flat despite increased food costs
Bankers reported tighter credit standards and weaker loan demand than in the previous survey
Production levels and new orders increased considerably, especially for non-durable goods
Residential sales improved modestly since the last survey period, but still remained well below year-ago levels
Air travel remained slightly higher than year-ago levels, and hotel occupancy rates were stable but below expectations
Agricultural conditions improved since the last report
Wges increased moderately, while prices for many commodities and energy have decreased since mid July, but remain at relatively high levels
Wge increases were moderate
Exports of manufactured goods have increased across the District
Residential real estate remained slow
Consumer spending decreased slightly in some areas
Chicago reported improved crop conditions, although corn and soybean development was behind schedule
Kansas City reported a slight improvement
Philadelphia reported moderate wage gains and limited hiring
All the Districts reporting on loan standards noted tightening
Manufacturing activity was weak or declining in most Districts but improved in others
Dallas reported an increase in office leasing but at a slower pace than in the last report
Consumer spending was slow in most Districts

Finally, bankers report weakening demand for both residential and commercial mortgages, widespread declines in refinancing activity, continued tightening in credit standards, and increasing delinquency rates on home mortgages
For all loan categories, respondents again indicate a tightening of credit standards
Contacts continue to note fairly widespread escalation in their selling prices (prices received) and expect increasingly widespread increases in the next six months
Housing markets in the District have been steady to weaker
Broadway theaters report that business has improved moderately since the last report
Bank lending continued to grow slowly
Firms also indicated that hiring is currently limited to the "most critical positions
Several banks indicated they were tightening credit standards
Around one-half of the surveyed manufacturers noted steady shipments, and the number reporting declines was just slightly greater than the number reporting increases
Commercial real estate firms indicated that construction and leasing activity continued to be very slow in August
Many dealerships were being closed or consolidated
Accordingly, corn silage yields were down and producers also expected corn for grain yield to be below normal
Retail sales were soft despite recent tax holidays and rebates; a few auto dealers reported low but nearly steady sales

Demand was somewhat strong in Raleigh, NC, average in Cary, NC, and weak in Hagerstown, Md  Some contacts expected demand to strengthen over the next few months due to a general strengthening in the local economy
Commercial loan activity softened a bit in recent weeks as somewhat weaker demand combined with tighter loan standards
Services firms reduced their payrolls slightly, while average wage growth remained stable since our last report

Leasing activity slowed in Richmond, Va, Columbia, SC, and the outlying areas of Wshington, DC, picked up slightly in Charleston, WVa, and Greensboro, NC, and remained flat in Raleigh, NC, and Baltimore, Md  Office vacancy rates were "creeping up" in northern Virginia and Richmond, Va, but were generally unchanged elsewhere
Retailers continued to cut jobs, though at a slower pace in recent weeks; average retail wages grew a bit more quickly
Overall demand remained high for petroleum products, with further expansion in extraction activity noted
Most retailers saw sluggish sales, and demand for services weakened
Upward price pressures remained significant

Asset quality deteriorated a bit further on net, with scattered reports of more severe deterioration and concerns about additional bank failures, especially among community banks that have been stressed by poorly performing construction loans
District manufacturing activity was mixed across sectors but appeared to expand overall during the survey period
Demand for new and existing homes continued to languish, resulting in further price declines
Retail sales remained sluggish

The overall condition of corn, soybeans, rice, and sorghum has improved slightly or acquired roughly the same percentage of poor ratings as in our previous report; however, a higher percentage of cotton was rated in poor condition
Compared with a year ago, retail sales were flat in July and the first half of August, while auto sales declined
Credit standards for consumer loans were also tightened somewhat, while demand for these loans was moderately weaker
Activity in the District's service sector has softened in most areas since our previous report
A contact in northeast Arkansas reported that commercial building was slow
Essentials and staple food items were strong sellers, while non-essential items and luxury goods moved more slowly
